intro: Lepidium pholidogynum, commonly known as the Mexican peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other mustard plants. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and slender, branching stems. Its leaves are alternate and pinnately divided, often with a slightly hairy texture. Lepidium pholidogynum is adapted to arid environments and is often found in desert and semi-desert regions.
